response_text: Firstly, I really liked how we were able to apply our learning multimodally through many different components — we completed both timed exams and written assignments, which allowed me to hone a wide range of transferable skills. Studying for an exam, for instance, helped me develop my awareness of time management and effective study strategies, while the writing assignments trained my ability to write clearly and concisely. In terms of the 'Class Participation' component of our grade, I really liked our weekly Slack discussion posts, and agree that Slack is an accessible and easily navigable platform to host the discussion posts. I also really liked how office hours occurred over Zoom, as this made them much more accessible.Beyond that, in regards to Dr. Huettel, our TAs (Christina and Qiaochu), and the learning environment that they created, I would definitely say that I felt supported — I was able to reach out to them super easily, whether it be speaking with them in person after class or sending them emails (which I would receive quick replies to), and I felt encouraged and empowered to raise my hand in class despite sitting in a crowd of over 100 students (Dr. Huettel was awesome at creating a judgment-free environment, where he encouraged us to disregard failure and the fear of providing a 'wrong' answer). Part of this was due to how engaging the class environment was in general, and while a big reason for this was how engaging of a speaker Dr. Huettel himself was (he delivered information through vivid stories and examples in such memorable ways (with humor too); a student on RateMyProfessors described his lectures as super interesting TED Talks, and I agree!), it's also because Dr. Huettel only released the lecture slides after the lecture itself, which kept everyone present.In terms of timed exams, the mini-exam (worth 3% of our grade) we took at the start of the semester was also a great incentive for me to stay on top of my content review while also understanding the systems of thinking used within the Decision Science field (reflected in the questions presented). More importantly, the mini-exam offered a small buffer for 'failure,' which I could learn from (without the 'failure' affecting my overall grade too consequentially).

response_text: This class is extremely interesting and I feel that Professor Vanberg is a great lecturer that will make you learn a lot about strategic situations and a nice guy. Having said that, while the class is initially very easy, especially if you have a basic understanding of game theory, it quickly ramps up in intensity and difficulty towards the latter half of the semester. While not insanely mathematical, it is definitely a quantitative course and the exams often give little time to solve complex problems. If you really want to guarantee an A, do not take this course unless you can dedicate a good amount of effort and time to the course as it escalates in difficulty. The grading scheme this semester for exams led to very high-variance outcomes: Relatively large portions of your grade could be lost by very silly mistakes and there were few partial credit opportunities. It is pretty easy to get a solid grade but very hard to get a very good grade.
